body.p: What to say about the year 2025? Mostly variations on the same theme as other parts of the 2020s. The same pattern of occasional expeditions to Mauritius or (mostly) France in the intervals of medical appointments and family gatherings; the same occasional excursion. I continued to pootle around with Victorian dramas, giving rise to occasional blog postings, and even the occasional academic conference. Some highlights are listed below.

JanuaryOn the 10th, I made many jars of marmalade. It's hard, but someone has to. On the 11th we went back to Oxford, overnighting at the Easy Hotel in Summertown before joining the throng celebrating Hazel's 80th birthday. Back in Bristol we were taken for an outing to Kings Weston House by Pam and Philip: nice architecture, though the cake shop was not as fancy as we had been led to believe. On the 24th, I was rather impressed by T. Chalamet's performance as the young Bob Dylan in a movie called "A complete unknown", showing at the luxurious Everyman cinema on Whiteladies Rd. I was so much older then.

February On the 8th we escaped to Mauritius for a month or so, staying in two different beach hotels, and a third floor flat in Curepipe. We also experienced a tropical storm called Garance, my first such experience: full details are in my holiday report

March Our arrival back in Bristol on the 3rd was fairly horrible, mostly because of the journey but also because as we staggered out of the bus station in search of the Uber, L realised she had left her phone and kindle on the bus now heading off to the land of Wales. This led to much to and fro with the Flixbus website and with assorted insurance companies, but culminated in a trip to Newport on the 28th where she was reunited with her gadgets, and I saw some rather splendid monuments commemorating the Newport Raising of 1839. We need more chartists.

April For our first French trip of the year, we experimented with a flight from Bristol to Bordeaux on the 6th, staying the night there before taking the 1026 TER to Limoges (arr 1248), proceeding via another TER to Gueret which arrived just in time for the 1430 TAD. But what we did for the next four weeks in La Vergne before catching the train back to England, I have no idea.

At the start of May, I went to Oxford for a college reunion: a Gaudy lunch at Balliol. This was surprisingly enjoyable: the food was good and both Carl Schmidt and Nick Shrimpton allowed me to drone on about Lacy at them. People I did not remember at all seemed to remember me, which is curiously satisfying; and my, how old we all are. Later in the month, we had an excursion to Bath with P&P to see Opera Luna's version of the Mikado, which I enjoyed immensely. And at the very end of the month, we tried another route into France, viz train to Portsmouth (the caribbean resto opposite the station is actually quite good), and the late afternoon ferry to Ouistreham, where we stayed a couple of nights in the Hotel "Le Cosy Riva Bella", enabling us to explore the Normandy beach a bit.

June From Ouistreham, we proceeded by bus and train to Coutances, and then by bus to La Haye where Jef and Nicole came to meet us. We stayed in a slightly odd Air BNB in La Haye, and did some seaside expeditions with Jef, still in his corset. On the 5th, we left them at Valognes and took the train to La Souterraine, via (inevitably) Paris, and started our proper summer holiday in La Vergne. The grass grew high, there were cherries on the trees and lambs in the fields. Evelyne took us out for dinner at the end of the month.

July We spent the whole month in La Vergne, doing nothing in particular. P&P came for a 48 hour visit : they tested the new bed (it worked, though the hot water did not); they also took us out for L's birthday lunch. There was a brocante around the reservoir, and at the end of the month we went out with everyone else to celebrate Evelyne's birthday at the Royal Wok (eat as much as you can) before reluctantly returning to Bristol via La Souterraine and Paris.

During August we were on grandparent duty, first in Nottingham for Harvey's birthday, and then to Maryland for Daphne's birthday bowling party at Stratford on the 9th. As has been their habit, Belinda and family passed through Bristol on their way to Cornwall on the 16th: we vacated the house to put them up, which gave us an excuse to sample Channings hotel: a pretty good breakfast, if not up to German standards. On the 21st P&P took us on another agreeable outing, by train to Freshford, along the banks of the Avon to Bradford on Same and back by train. And at the end of the month, I flew off to Berlin all on my own in order to participate in the Dracor Summit at the Free University of Berlin. Very exciting. Getting from the airport to the campus by U-bahn and S-bahn after dark was also quite exciting.

September I stayed in Berlin until the 5th, relishing the novel experience of being on a well-funded European university campus and staying in a posh hotel. Then I took the slow route back to La Vergne, via Mannheim, Karlsruhe, Paris, and La Souterraine. On the 20th, after another largely uneventful fortnight in La Vergne, I left for Bristol via Paris, again. On the 27th Kev had a surprise 50th birthday party in a pub in Easton.

October On the 14th I nipped off to Caen, by train, for a meeting of the CaeSAR Project scientific council, which was fun, though I am still not sure how exactly it will accelerate research. I saw some of my Lacy texts being presented by MAX, but only momentarily. I stayed two nights in a very noisy hotel over a bar in the centre of Caen, before MrsH was shamed into moving me to a much nicer one near the station. Being in France, I was then unable to resist the temptation of the lengthy but increasingly familiar train journey, from Caen to La Souterraine, via Tours and Vierzon. It takes more than five hours, but so does the alternative so-called high speed route via Paris. Then I had another week or so in La Vergne, during which there was much wind and tempest, sufficient to uproot one of the two mighty walnut trees in the back garden. It fell on top of Patrice's recently erected fence, which is probably why he seemed to take a gloomy delight in reducing it to a heap of logs over the next few days. I then retraced my railway steps as far as Tours where I yet again taught the ever popular "TEI Niveau 1" from the 27th to the 29th, before returning once more back to London and Bristol on the 30th.

From the 6th to the 8th of November I stayed in one of the many cheapish minimalist hotels around Kings Cross. The occasion was a "study day" hosted by the British Library on the 7th, where I met and tried to impress some Victorian Studies glitterati. Organised jointly with the Caen Punch Project, the day involved much discussion of Punch visuals and some interesting snippets of background history, notably my first encounter with Patrick Leary and Henry Silver's diary. BL staff were on strike, but still supplied masses of fairly horrid sandwiches. And at the end of the month, I yet again popped over to Caen by Eurostar, this time for the MRSH Scientific Committee. But this was my last expedition of the year: I did not proceed from there to La Vergne, and was back in Bristol for the 22nd.

Which was just as well, since on the 5th December, L fell over in mysterious circumstances on the way home, fracturing her clavicule, Which meant that almost all amusements planned for December had to be cancelled. On the plus side, I got to know the route to and from the BRI rather well; the NHS was wonderful; and we were still able to have an extensive Xmas lunch with Elizabeth and co, plus a boxing day amusement at Sarah's house with everyone except the Nottingham family branch, who did however come to join us for New Years eve.
